articles.headline: The Boycott That Wasn’t: How United Weathered a Media Firestorm
articles.snippet: Three months after an infamous video, United Airlines’ earnings were surprisingly robust, perhaps proof that people ultimately shop for convenience and price.
articles.abstract: Three months after an infamous video, United Airlines’ earnings were surprisingly robust, perhaps proof that people ultimately shop for convenience and price.
articles.lead_paragraph: After videos of David Dao, a medical doctor who in April was dragged kicking and screaming off an overbooked United Airlines plane, went viral and set off a global uproar, the outlook for United looked grim. Within days, the Twitter hashtag #BoycottUnited had been used over 3.5 million times.

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Forced Unwanted Auto Insurance on Borrowers
articles.snippet: An internal report shows customers with car loans had costly, unnecessary insurance tacked onto their bills, and 274,000 were pushed into delinquency.
articles.abstract: An internal report shows customers with car loans had costly, unnecessary insurance tacked onto their bills, and 274,000 were pushed into delinquency.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 800,000 people who took out car loans from Wells Fargo were charged for auto insurance they did not need, and some of them are still paying for it, according to an internal report prepared for the bank’s executives.

articles.headline: Senate Rejects Slimmed-Down Obamacare Repeal as McCain Votes No
articles.snippet: The party’s senators trimmed their vision of a bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, but three Republicans turned on the bill in the dead of night.
articles.abstract: The party’s senators trimmed their vision of a bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, but three Republicans turned on the bill in the dead of night.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate in the early hours of Friday morning rejected a new, scaled-down Republican plan to repeal parts of the Affordable Care Act, derailing the Republicans’ seven-year campaign to dismantle President Barack Obama’s signature health care law and dealing a huge political setback to President Trump.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Wisconsin’s Lavish Lure for Foxconn: $3 Billion in Tax Subsidies
articles.snippet: The incentive package includes $1.5 billion in state income tax credits for job creation and $1.35 billion in state income tax breaks for capital investment.
articles.abstract: The incentive package includes $1.5 billion in state income tax credits for job creation and $1.35 billion in state income tax breaks for capital investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Foxconn’s plan for a $10 billion factory in Wisconsin is certainly good news for President Trump and Republican politicians Gov. Scott Walker and Speaker Paul D. Ryan, whose district the plant would call home.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz, Patricia Cohen and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: In One Day, Trump Administration Lands 3 Punches Against Gay Rights
articles.snippet: Activists called Wednesday the White House’s “anti-L.G.B.T. day” after it barred transgender people from the military, intervened in an employment suit and nominated a gay rights opponent as an ambassador.
articles.abstract: Activists called Wednesday the White House’s “anti-L.G.B.T. day” after it barred transgender people from the military, intervened in an employment suit and nominated a gay rights opponent as an ambassador.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration abruptly waded into the culture wars over gay rights this week, signaling in three separate actions that it will use the powers of the federal government to roll back civil rights for gay and transgender people.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Who’s in Congo’s Mass Graves? And Why Are Soldiers Guarding Them?
articles.snippet: Soldiers are stationed at grave sites that could expose a massacre by the security forces, as Congolese civilians are caught between warring sides.
articles.abstract: Soldiers are stationed at grave sites that could expose a massacre by the security forces, as Congolese civilians are caught between warring sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANANGA, Democratic Republic of Congo — They are everywhere. Here next to a house, where a woman is hanging clothes to dry. There in a field, where children are playing.

articles.headline: Nawaz Sharif, Pakistan’s Prime Minister, Is Toppled by Corruption Case
articles.snippet: Mr. Sharif stepped down after the Supreme Court ordered him removed from office, roiling the country’s fragile political balance.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sharif stepped down after the Supreme Court ordered him removed from office, roiling the country’s fragile political balance.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Nawaz Sharif, the tycoon and party leader who helped define a turbulent era of Pakistani politics, stepped down as prime minister on Friday after the Supreme Court ruled that corruption allegations had disqualified him.

articles.headline: Spain’s Long Economic Nightmare Is Finally Over
articles.snippet: After nearly a decade of economic crisis, Spain is finally growing again, underscoring hopes that the eurozone has reached a healthier place.
articles.abstract: After nearly a decade of economic crisis, Spain is finally growing again, underscoring hopes that the eurozone has reached a healthier place.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARTORELL, Spain — Inside a factory as cavernous as an airport terminal, half-built cars glide down the assembly line in a parade that never ends. Workers in coveralls sidle up on queue, attending to the meticulously timed tasks of turning steel into road-ready sedans.

articles.headline: Riding Out the Senate Debate With a Massachusetts Medicaid Guru
articles.snippet: Nearly two-thirds of people in nursing homes rely on Medicaid to pay at least some of the bill. And many of them rely on specialists like Estelle Stasz for help.
articles.abstract: Nearly two-thirds of people in nursing homes rely on Medicaid to pay at least some of the bill. And many of them rely on specialists like Estelle Stasz for help.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTHAMPTON, Mass. — As the health care debate in Washington descended into absurdity this week — with senators not knowing the content of bills they were preparing to amend, and supporting unwritten bills they hoped wouldn’t become law — there were at least two categories of people waiting out the results.

articles.headline: U.S. Growth Accelerates, but Remains Short of Pace Promised by Trump
articles.snippet: The Commerce Department’s report is a sign that the economy remains on track, with underlying growth in line with levels since the current recovery began.
articles.abstract: The Commerce Department’s report is a sign that the economy remains on track, with underlying growth in line with levels since the current recovery began.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy’s trajectory in President Trump’s first year in office is looking a lot like it did during President Barack Obama’s last year in office.

articles.headline: McCain Provides a Dramatic Finale on Health Care: Thumb Down
articles.snippet: Critics said he had come back to the Senate preaching the virtues of bipartisanship but not practicing it. They were wrong.
articles.abstract: Critics said he had come back to the Senate preaching the virtues of bipartisanship but not practicing it. They were wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — All week long, Senate Democrats had quietly groused that Senator John McCain made a stirring return to the Senate after a brain cancer diagnosis, that he preached the virtues of bipartisanship — and that he then backed a Republican-only push to replace the Affordable Care Act.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Have Bipartisan Health Ideas. Now to Persuade Their Leaders ...
articles.snippet: The professions of a desire for cooperation on changing the Affordable Care Act were as profuse on Friday as the short-term outlook for tangible results was grim.
articles.abstract: The professions of a desire for cooperation on changing the Affordable Care Act were as profuse on Friday as the short-term outlook for tangible results was grim.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional lawmakers said on Friday that the collapse of Republican efforts to demolish the Affordable Care Act had created an opening for bipartisan work to shore up health insurance markets and protect consumers against sharp increases in premiums.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: North Korea Tests a Ballistic Missile That Experts Say Could Hit California
articles.snippet: The missile flew on a high trajectory that, if lowered, may allow it to reach large American cities, a milestone for the North’s weapons program, experts say.
articles.abstract: The missile flew on a high trajectory that, if lowered, may allow it to reach large American cities, a milestone for the North’s weapons program, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: North Korea tested an intercontinental ballistic missile on Friday that, for the first time, appeared capable of reaching the West Coast of the United States, according to experts — a milestone that American presidents have long declared the United States could not tolerate.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Choe Sang-Hun and William J. Broad
